title: Cheap Ways to Unclog an Ink Cartridge

steps.title: Find a bathroom close by that has a sink that can give you hot water.
steps.content: Find a bathroom close by that has a sink that can give you hot water. The closer the better

steps.title: Place some old newspapers or paper towels in the counter of the sink.
steps.content: Place some old newspapers or paper towels in the counter of the sink. We don't want ink everywhere.

steps.title: Make sure your printer is plugged in and your computer has the printer drivers installed.
steps.content: Make sure your printer is plugged in and your computer has the printer drivers installed.

steps.title: Open the printer up to reveal the ink cartridges.
steps.content: Open the printer up to reveal the ink cartridges.

steps.title: Take out the black ink cartridge.
steps.content: Take out the black ink cartridge. This trick might work for a colored ink cartridge, but it's probably a better idea to use a black cartridge.

steps.title: Take the cartridge to the sink and put it down on the old newspaper or paper towels.
steps.content: Take the cartridge to the sink and put it down on the old newspaper or paper towels. Try to rest it sort of diagonally so that the part where the ink actually comes out isn't completely touching the paper towel or you could have a mess.

steps.title: Turn on the sink and wait until you can get very hot water.
steps.content: Turn on the sink and wait until you can get very hot water.

steps.title: Pull that thing behind the sink handle that closes the drain and keeps water in the sink.
steps.content: Pull that thing behind the sink handle that closes the drain and keeps water in the sink.

steps.title: Let the sink fill with hot water, but ONLY a little bit.
steps.content: Let the sink fill with hot water, but ONLY a little bit. No more than 3/4" from the very bottom.

steps.title: Place the cartridge in the sink so the part where the ink comes out is in the water.
steps.content: Place the cartridge in the sink so the part where the ink comes out is in the water. Make sure it gets past the surface of the water. Ink may (and probably will) come out, don't be alarmed!

steps.title: If ink comes out immediately then your cartridge isn't terribly clogged.
steps.content: If ink comes out immediately then your cartridge isn't terribly clogged. About 5 minutes in the sink should do the trick. Otherwise, you might have to wait up to 20 minutes.

steps.title: Dry off the cartridge so it's no more than damp, and put it back in the printer and give it a test run.
steps.content: Dry off the cartridge so it's no more than damp, and put it back in the printer and give it a test run.

steps.title: Attach the hose to the Print cartridge nozzle , closing the gap with blue-or white tack or plasticine.
steps.content: Attach the hose to the Print cartridge nozzle , closing the gap with blue-or white tack or plasticine.

steps.title: For only a few seconds at a time, turn on vacuum adjusting the suction with the regulator or speed control and leave the cartridge in the vertical nozzle down position.
steps.content: For only a few seconds at a time, turn on vacuum adjusting the suction with the regulator or speed control and leave the cartridge in the vertical nozzle down position.

steps.title: Repeat process until the nozzle is cleared.
steps.content: Repeat process until the nozzle is cleared.

steps.title: Blot off the excess ink with toilet roll.
steps.content: Blot off the excess ink with toilet roll.

steps.title: Determine what type of cartridge you have.
steps.content: Determine what type of cartridge you have. This should be either electronic, sponge or open head. Electronic heads are normally covered with orange wire strips. Sponge heads are obviously sponge which can be touched. Open heads are a hole with nothing in them but ink. For electronic heads, simply throw in trash. These heads are unreliable, especially if you don't print every day. Get rid of your printer. Give it away. Deliver it to your local thrift store. Buy a printer with sponge or open heads. These almost never dry out because the system keeps them sealed. Usually you will find these in printers with four or more cartridges; three separate colors and one black (aka CMYK). If you have a sponge or open head cartridge, and you already did the other methods to no avail, your cartridge is dead. The ink has dried and hardened to a point it cannot be salvaged. Buy a new one. They can usually be found cheap on Ebay.
